body:
There's only so much information you can cram into one line.  It's easy to have more information in your statusline than can possibly fit, a long git branch name plus a long file path are enough to fill a single line.  While truncation helps, there is only so much you can truncate before the message becomes useless.  This issue becomes particularly acute when using a display in portrait mode.

The Japanese VIM group have prepared a [patch][1] to allow support for this feature, but it has been rejected and not allowed into the Vim core.  

### Actual behaviour

Statuslines are limited to a single line of text.

### Expected behaviour

The ability to set `statuslineheight` as documented in [the patch][1].  Here's an excerpt of the patch against documentation:

```
+			   *'statuslineheight'* *'stlh'*
+'statuslineheight' 'stlh'	number	(default 1)
+				global or local to window |global-local|
+				{not in Vi}
+				{not available when compiled without the
+				|+multi_statusline| feature}
+	Number of screen lines to use for the status line.
```

[1]: https://gist.github.com/h-east/3158492#comment-610265

comment_data.body: question is, do we want "wrap" of a single statusline string, or is it preferable to supply a pre-delimited array of one string per line?
Is there a popular editor which has mutiple statusline support? IMHO, multiple status lines are ugly.

Does it matter if a popular editor has it?

If you think it's ugly to have multiple lines, use the default single line.

As far as line wrap vs an array, in the best of all worlds you could have an array for the top and bottom of the screen.

But there is also the consideration of what is possible to do without breaking compatibility with all the things that integrate with the status bar.

I don't really know enough about the internals to say which approach is better on that front.

As mentioned on the vi.stackexchange I would argue, that this is not really needed, that now we do have floating windows or popups. If you really need that much more information, make use of those features.
welll that depends on if one "likes" the 'statusline' custom interpolation format. But I suppose we could hack something similar/better in lua for floats.
also floats do not take up "space" yet, like 'statusline' does, but I think we should be able to embed a one-line window below/above a "proper" split window, if we want to.

For my use case the desirable part of multiple status lines is the integration with existing plugins.

For example, in order to get a usable file path, I've had to remove the version control system info, file type, and encoding from my vim-airline config.

If there is a better way to display this kind of information than using status lines, then I am completely happy with that approach.

Ideally it's something low-magic enough that I can patch the plugins I use and offer pull requests without becoming a master of vim and neovim internals.

@daotoad  What is the use case for showing the full file path all the time?

If you just want to check the full file path, just press `2` followed by `ctrl-g`. If you want to show the full path always, I find a good place is the window title. I have the following setting:

```
set titlestring+=%(%{expand('%:p:~')}\ \ %)
set titlestring+=%{strftime('%Y-%m-%d\ %H:%M',getftime(expand('%')))}
```

It will show the absolute file path and its latest modify time.

jdhao, thanks for asking--I really appreciate the attention and thought going into this discussion.  I don't need the full path, but with my monitor in portrait mode I have just over 80 columns of text.  When you add in a branch name in from git following team standards, it looks like `feature/XY-3333-some-name-here-like-this`.  Add in react project file names like `src/components/SomeComponent/subComponent/reducers/someActionName.ts`, already things don't fit with the line number and column of the cursor position, much less the file type, encoding, messages from coc and so forth.

I can't just get by with the file name and not the path, because I have a bunch of files called `index.ts` or `cycles.ts`.

I have copious vertical space, even after splitting my window to keep a shell present below my code.

To consistently have enough file path visible I had to disable most of the airline defaults.

I know one solution is "don't structure your projects like that", but I am using these tools for work and I need to conform to the standards set by my team.  So the simple answer isn't really an option.

I would really love to be able to have the git information back.  The other stuff would be nice, but is far less important.  Perhaps I have an X Y problem, and there is a much better way to go forward than targeting the status line.  If so, I would love to hear an alternative approach.

Thanks again for your hard work and attention--this applies to all the neovim contributors, too.

--Edit:

Setting titlestring doesn't do anything noticeable in my tmux session.  Maybe there's a configuration thing I should change, I didn't find anything after a few minutes, I'll keep investigating, though.  It would be better than nothing, but since I have multiple buffers visible with horizontal splits, it would only show one path at the top of the window (or maybe at the bottom in the session list from tmux.

@daotoad  I am also seeing the same issue inside tmux. The titlestring can not be set correctly. The window title only shows `nvim: tmux`, not the actual file name. Outside tmux, the setting works for me.

> The window title only shows `nvim: tmux`, not the actual file name. Outside tmux, the setting works for me.

https://github.com/jamessan/etc-vim/blob/93e6136a1c66d05ee36cc5bdfa8251da56c84422/.vimrc#L86-L90 may help.

@jamessan  I tried the setting given. Unfortunately, it does not work for me (macOS, kitty, iterm2 both tried.)

Edit: will open a separate issue for this. Issue [here](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/12944).

I think this would really be very nice to have.

Nobody's suggesting that it be the default behaviour, nor are we suggesting that there aren't other alternative ways to display the information in question â€” but neither of those are really a reasonable argument *against* multi-statuslines; they just mean *you* don't want/need multi-statuslines.

Personally, I'd also love to see the full filename (or a longer-but-still-abbreviated filename) on every single split across my workstation; I easily have the screen-space for it. Manually hacking something together out of hovers just sounds â€¦ absurdly prone to breakage and failure, not to mention the time-investment for such a hack!

Anyway, that's my 2Â¢: ðŸ‘, this is worth having, even if a majority of users don't need it.
Then be the change you want. This is anyway an open source project. Anyone are free to work on it.
I think multi-line statuslines would also enable https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/13166 .

What about a new low level API for creating "bars", just like creating floating windows? A bar could:

- Be horizontal or vertical
- Be per window (like the status bar) or global (like the tabline)
- Be placed top, right, bottom or left
- Be multiple lines/columns thick

Status bar plugins like lualine could use this to create additional status bars, Git plugins could use vertical bars for more gutter space (plus, line information could be put on both the left and right side of a window), it could be used for writing a minimap plugin, the possibilities are endless.

> What about a new low level API for creating "bars", just like creating floating windows? A bar could:

This is essentially what was already suggested in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/12925#issuecomment-695332500 : 

> but I think we should be able to embed a one-line window below/above a "proper" split window, if we want to.

Essentially "docked" windows with perhaps extra behavior such as being skipped by `CTRL-w` and friends.

See also https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/15432
